title: Can a person really 'dislike' music? - Quora
tags: Why Do People Hate X So Much?

response.answer_text: Since I was young I have hated music. I avoid it wherever I can. In the last 50 years I have always switched of audio on all my devices and no longer visit cnn because news and music just don't go together. When I am in a place where music is unavoidable like a clothes shop I do what I have to and leave. As a student in university I put a audio cassette on autoplay and kept it running for a full year (sousa marches) as a way of covering the sound of my neighbours music. (After long enough the mind filters out repetitive sounds.) I find music interferes with my thinking to the end tent that I cannot talk, I struggle to walk and even the most basic activities like getting dressed become impossible. Music creates so much stress in my life that even typing this in a silent room is disturbing. My biggest nightmare is the phonecall where they put you on hold and force you to listen to their choice of music. So yes you can dislike music, and you can have stronger emotions too.

Yes. It isn't likely, but some people just don't like music. It's not to say they hate it all the time, but most of the time those people just prefer silence. I honestly don't know if there's anyone out there that has sworn off music forever, but I know some people that are so indifferent about music it's funny. They don't care about it at all and most of the time prefer silence instead of music.

Some people evolve / are born with different dopamine responses to certain stimuli such as music. They might "like" music more than someone who does not have an attendant dopaminergic response. Misophonia, a condition which affects the insular cortex, might result in the listener experiencing certain sounds as painful or irritating.

Music is *very* personal. One loves only music pre-Bach and another post-Webern. My own range is from Medieval and Renaissance through Bach, skip the “Mannheim” school and the go to Beethoven and continue through the Romantic. When it comes to mid-20th century forward, I pick and choose. This doesn’t mean that another person only listens to a particular period of pop or different periods classical. If music speaks to you, listen. Try to be open to other eras but you don’t have to like them and go back to them. If music pleases you, listen and enjoy! Happy listening.

I don't find music as pleasurable as most people and would really like it if cars were not equipped with radios. At times I feel trapped if I can't turn the sound off. It can feel like intense anger that floats just below the surface of the skin. I don't hate music though, and sometimes there are specific songs I can identify with but I'm super picky and may not want to hear it if I'm not in the mood.

Some people have "specific musical anhedonia". They don't get any pleasure from music. It's not that they hate it; it's just that it doesn't do anything for them. Others can be tone-deaf or have some inability to recognize music.http://www.theverge.com/2014/3/6/5477622/bad-brains-some-people-incapable-of-enjoying-music

In my opinion, music itself is personal. However, it depends on how a certain song reaches your ear. The clearest example of this is the visual, sentimental or sensory connotation we relate the song to. We can watch a movie and hear for the fist time a song at the most romantic moment and fell in love with it, or hear the best uplifting song in the climax of the story when the character decides to be the best (i.e. Rocky) It is very hard to judge a song if you have been forced to assosiate it with a moment that created an impact in you. Never the less you can hear a random song on the radio, club, supermarket and love it or hate it.

well, My personall opinion on this question is that music is both personal and not. You see when you listen to a kind of music or to a song you do it for various reasons, and the music speaks to you. Music is a way of commnication and expression and you have to find your own kind that expresses you. The thing is that music can be shared. You can feel the same things about songs with other people so then it’s not personall anymore.

Music from any artist that is sold for profit at any time is no longer personal. The line between art created from love and passion or profitable business is dissolved once a person accepts revenue for the very art that they create. Some would believe its the equivalent of selling your soul to the devil. So in relation to music you have ever heard and enjoyed from any artist, enjoy it for what it is but NO it was never personal. It was strictly capitalism because that is the American way.
